<!-- used if the second body changes the name of the legislation --> | passeddate2 = July 25, 2003 | passedvote2 = passed without objection | conferencedate = | passedbody3 = | passeddate3 = | passedvote3 = | agreedbody3 = <!-- used when the other body agrees without going into committee --> | agreeddate3 = <!-- used when the other body agrees without going into committee --> | agreedvote3 = <!-- used when the other body agrees without going into committee --> | agreedbody4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreeddate4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreedvote4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | passedbody4 = | passeddate4 = | passedvote4 = | signedpresident = [[George W. Bush]] | signeddate = September 4, 2003 | unsignedpresident = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | unsigneddate = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | vetoedpresident = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | vetoeddate = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | amendments = [[Second Chance Act of 2007]] | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Prison Rape Elimination Act of 2003''' ('''PREA''') is the first United States federal law intended to deter the [[Prison rape in the United States|sexual assault of prisoners]]. The bill was signed into law on September 4, 2003.
==Background== {{Further information|Prison rape in the United States}}
Public awareness of [[Prison rape in the United States|prison rape]] is relatively recent and estimates of its [[prevalence]] vary widely.
In 1974 Carl Weiss and David James Friar wrote that 46 million [[Incarceration in the United States|Americans would one day be incarcerated]]; of that number, they claimed, 10 million would be raped.<ref name="peek" /> A 1992 estimate from the [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]] conjectured that between 9 and 20 percent of inmates had been sexually assaulted.<ref name="peek" /> Studies in 1982 and 1996 both concluded that the rate was somewhere between 12 and 14 percent. A 1986 study by Daniel Lockwood put the number at around 23 percent for [[Incarceration in the United States#Security levels|maximum security prison]]s in New York.<ref name="peek" /> In contrast, Christine Saum's 1994 survey of 101 inmates showed 5 had been sexually assaulted.<ref name="peek">{{cite journal|last=Peek|first=Christine|year=2003|title=Breaking Out of the Prison Hierarchy: Transgendered Prisoners, Rape, and the Eighth Amendment|journal=Santa Clara Law Review|publisher=[[Santa Clara University School of Law]]|volume=44|issue=Entire Paragraph citation|pages=1211–48|issn=0146-0315|oclc=2842601|url=http://www.hawaii.edu/hivandaids/Tg/Breaking_Out_of_the_Prison_Hierarchy__Transgender_Prisoners,_Rape,_and_the_Eighth_Amendment.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2008-06-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010170831/http://www.hawaii.edu/hivandaids/Tg/Breaking_Out_of_the_Prison_Hierarchy__Transgender_Prisoners,_Rape,_and_the_Eighth_Amendment.pdf|archivedate=2008-10-10|df=}}</ref>
In 2001 [[Human Rights Watch]] (HRW) released a paper called "[[No Escape: Male Rape in U.S. Prisons]]", the single event that contributed most to PREA's passage two years later.<ref name="smith" /> HRW had published several papers on the topic of prison rape in the years since its initial report called "All Too Familiar: Sexual Abuse of Women in U.S. State Prisons", released in 1996, when there was barely any Congressional support for legislation aimed at [[prison rape]].<ref name="smith" /> A 1998 attempt by Representative [[John Conyers, Jr.]] (D-MI), known as the Custodial Sexual Abuse Act of 1998, was attached to the reauthorization bill for the [[Violence Against Women Act]] but summarily removed and never reintroduced.<ref name="smith">{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Brenda V.|date=Spring 2008|title=The Prison Rape Elimination Act: Implementation and Unresolved Issues|journal=Criminal Law Brief|publisher=[[Washington College of Law]]|issue=WCL Research Paper No. 2008–49|oclc=63521701|ssrn=1129810|accessdate=}}</ref>
[[Michael J. Horowitz (lawyer)|Michael Horowitz]], a [[Hudson Institute]] [[senior fellow]], has been credited with playing a part in passing PREA by helping to lead a coalition of the bill's supporters.<ref name="teret" />
==Support and lobby== The Prison Rape Elimination Act of 2003 was supported by a broad base of activists, lobbyists, and organizations, particularly [[Just Detention International]]. The [[Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission|Southern Baptist Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission]] lobbied for the passage of the legislation as did the conservative organization [[Concerned Women for America]].<ref name="fox">{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,97392,00.html|title=Confronting Prison Rape|last=[[Wendy McElroy|McElroy, Wendy]]|date=September 16, 2003|publisher=[[Fox News]]|accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref> These groups were part of a diverse coalition of human rights and religious groups which backed the legislation; other groups which supported the act were: [[Amnesty International USA]], [[Focus on the Family]], [[Human Rights Watch]], the [[NAACP]], the [[National Association of Evangelicals]], [[Penal Reform International]], [[Physicians for Human Rights]], the [[Presbyterian Church USA]], [[Prison Fellowship]], the [[Salvation Army]] and the [[Union of American Hebrew Congregations]].<ref name="strode">{{cite news|url=http://www.sbcbaptistpress.org/bpnews.asp?ID=16630|title=Law targeting prison rape signed; diverse coalition backed measure|last=Strode|first=Tom|date=September 3, 2003|publisher=[[Baptist Press]]|accessdate=2008-06-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327163535/http://www.sbcbaptistpress.org/bpnews.asp?ID=16630|archivedate=March 27, 2008|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.prisonlegalnews.org/news/2013/sep/15/prison-rape-elimination-act-standards-finally-in-effect-but-will-they-be-effective/|title=Prison Rape Elimination Act Standards Finally in Effect, but Will They be Effective?|date=September 15, 2003|publisher=Prison Legal News|accessdate=2016-12-06}}</ref>
The bill was sponsored, in both houses of the [[U.S. Congress]], by a bipartisan group of legislators. The initial sponsors of the bill in the [[United States Senate|Senate]] were [[Ted Kennedy|Edward Kennedy]] (D-[[Massachusetts|MA]]) and [[Jeff Sessions]] (R-[[Alabama|AL]]) and, in the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] the legislation was sponsored by Representative [[Frank Wolf (politician)|Frank Wolf]] (R-[[Virginia|VA]]) and Rep. [[Robert C. Scott|Bobby Scott]] (D-VA), who was the initial co-sponsor.<ref name=strode/> The Senate bill picked up four co-sponsors on the day it was passed, they were: Senators [[Mike DeWine]] (R-[[Ohio|OH]]), [[Dick Durbin]] (D-[[Illinois|IL]]), and [[Dianne Feinstein]] (D-[[California|CA]]).<ref name=thomas/> The House bill had a total of 32 co-sponsors, including Scott.<ref name=thomas2>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d108:HR01707: H.R.1707 - Bill Summary & Status File]", ''[[The Library of Congress]]'' [[THOMAS|THOMAS.gov]], September 4, 2003 (last update), accessed June 5, 2008.</ref> The bill passed both the House and Senate by [[unanimous consent]]; it passed the Senate on July 21, 2003, and the House on July 25.<ref name=thomas>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d108:s.01435: S.1435 - Bill Summary & Status File]", ''[[The Library of Congress]]'' [[THOMAS|THOMAS.gov]], September 4, 2003 (last update), accessed June 5, 2008.</ref><ref name=juveniletxt>"[http://ojjdp.ncjrs.org/about/PubLNo108-79.txt Public Law 108-79, September 4, 2003] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080526032451/http://ojjdp.ncjrs.org/about/PubLNo108-79.txt |date=May 26, 2008 }}", ''[[Office of Justice Programs|Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Programs]]'', [[United States Department of Justice]], September 4, 2003, accessed June 5, 2008.</ref>
==Act==
===Provisions=== The Act was passed by both houses of the [[U.S. Congress]] and subsequently signed by President [[George W. Bush]] in a [[White House]] ceremony on September 4, 2003.<ref name=policechief>Jordan, Andrew, Morgan, Marcia, and McCampbell, Michael. "[http://policechiefmagazine.org/magazine/index.cfm?fuseaction=display_arch&article_id=864&issue_id=42006 The Prison Rape Elimination Act: What Police Chiefs Need to Know]", ''The Police Chief'', vol. 73, no. 4, April 2006, accessed June 3, 2008.</ref><ref name=briefing>"[https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2003/09/20030904-4.html#2 Press Gaggle by Scott McClellan Aboard Air Force One en route to Kansas City, Missouri]", ''[[The White House]]'', ([[Press conference|Press briefing transcript]]), September 4, 2003.</ref> The act aimed to curb prison rape through a "zero-tolerance" policy, as well as thorough research and information gathering. The act called for developing national standards to prevent incidents of sexual violence in prison. It also made policies more available and obvious. By making data on prison rape more available to the prison administrators as well as making corrections facilities more accountable for incidents pertaining to sexual violence and of prison rape it would more than likely decrease the crimes.<ref name=nij>National Institute of Justice Staff, "[http://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/nij/213137.pdf NIJ's Response to the Prison Rape Elimination Act]", ([[PDF]]), ''Corrections Today'', February 2006, accessed June 5, 2008.</ref>
A major component of the PREA was the establishment of a "National Prison Rape Reduction Commission".<ref name=policechief/> The panel was established by the act and appointed in June 2004, though the law itself called for the commission's creation within 60 days of its passage.<ref name=juveniletxt/><ref name=nytimes>Marshall, Carolyn. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/20/politics/20rape.html Panel on Prison Rape Hears Victims' Chilling Accounts ]", ''[[The New York Times]], August 20, 2005, accessed June 3, 2008.</ref> The panel, known as the [[National Prison Rape Elimination Commission]] (NPREC), was charged with undertaking a study on the comprehensive effects of prison rape and its occurrences.<ref name=juveniletxt/> The commission was also charged with information gathering through a variety of sources including public hearings. Eventually the commission will issue a report which includes its findings, conclusions and any recommendations.<ref name=about>"[http://www.nprec.us/about.htm About NPREC] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080508054836/http://nprec.us/about.htm |date=2008-05-08 }}", ''National Prison Rape Elimination Commission'', accessed June 5, 2008.</ref>
In addition the law mandated that the [[U.S. Department of Justice]] (DOJ) "make the prevention of prison rape a top priority in each prison system".<ref name=juveniletxt/> The DOJ's [[Bureau of Justice Statistics]] was mandated to produce an annual report on its activities concerning the topic of prison rape in the U.S. prison system.<ref name=juveniletxt/> The law also made several other mandates for the DOJ. The [[National Institute of Corrections]] (NIC) was ordered to offer training and technical assistance, provide a clearinghouse for information and produce its own annual report to Congress. PREA required the DOJ to create a review panel designed to conduct hearings on prison rape, this panel was given subpoena power as well. At the top of the Justice Department PREA authorized the Attorney General to dispense grant money to facilitate implementation of the act. These grants are administered by the [[Bureau of Justice Assistance]] (BJA) and the [[National Institute of Justice]] (NIJ).<ref name="2006rept">{{cite web|url=http://www.spr.org/pdf/NIC_report_2006.pdf|format=PDF|title=Report to the Congress of the United States on the Activities of the Department of Justice in Relation to the Prison Rape Elimination Act (Public Law 108-79)|date=July 2006|publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]], [[National Institute of Corrections]]|accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref>
Representative [[Danny K. Davis]] (D-IL) introduced the Second Chance Act of 2007 on March 20 of that year, among its provisions was an amendment to PREA. The miscellaneous provisions of what was largely a law designed to help reintegrate criminal offenders into the community, extended the existence of the NPREC from 3 to 5 years after its inception date.<ref name=thomas3>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:h.r.01593: H.R. 1593 - Bill Summary & Status File]", ''[[The Library of Congress]]'' [[THOMAS|THOMAS.gov]], April 9, 2008 (last update), accessed June 5, 2008.</ref> The Senate version was introduced nine days later and sponsored by then-Senator [[Joe Biden]] (D-[[Delaware|DE]]). The Second Chance Act passed the House 347–62 on November 13, 2007. The bill passed the Senate by unanimous consent on March 11, 2008, and the life of the NPREC was extended when Bush signed the Second Chance Act of 2007 on April 9, 2008.<ref name=thomas3/>
===Juvenile justice=== PREA covers all adult, as well as juvenile detention facilities; the definition of prison for the purposes of the act includes "any juvenile facility used for the custody or care of juvenile inmates."<ref name=juveniletxt/> U.S. Congress, within the text of PREA, noted that young, first-time offenders are at an increased risk of sexually motivated crimes. Juveniles held in adult facilities are five times more likely to be sexually assaulted than juveniles held in juvenile facilities.<ref name=juveniletxt/>
===Signing statement=== Upon signing PREA, Bush issued a [[signing statement (United States)|signing statement]] to accompany the law's passage.<ref name="list">{{cite web|url=http://www.coherentbabble.com/signingstatements/TOCindex.htm|title=Signing Statements: George W. Bush|last=Greene|first=Joyce A.|date=2006, 2007<!--, 2008-->|publisher=Coherentbabble.com|accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref><ref name=statement/> The signing statement specifically exempted the [[Executive (government)|executive branch]] from two parts of section 7 of PREA.<ref name="statement">{{cite web|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2003/09/20030904-9.html|title=Statement on Prison Rape Elimination Act|last=Bush|first=George W.|date=2003-09-04|publisher=[[The White House]]|accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref> Section 7 deals with access for the NPREC to any federal department or agency's information that it deemed necessary to complete its job.<ref name=juveniletxt/> The two specific sections that the signing statement allowed the executive branch to ignore if "disclosure could impair deliberative processes of the Executive or the performance of the Executive's constitutional duties" were 7(h) and 7(k)3.<ref name=statement/> The signing statement maintained that this was within the Constitutional authority of the president.<ref name=statement/>
===Temporary lock-ups=== PREA defines "[[prison]]" quite broadly, as "any federal, state, or local confinement facility, including local jails, police lockups, juvenile facilities, and state and federal prisons."<ref name="teret">{{cite journal|last=Teret|first=Stephen P.|author2=Julie Samia Mair|author3=Shannon Frattaroli|date=Winter 2003|title=New Hope for Victims of Prison Sexual Assault|journal=The Journal of Law, Medicine & Ethics|publisher=American Society of Law, Medicine & Ethics via [[Just Detention International]]|issn=1073-1105|url=http://www.justdetention.org/pdf/HopeforHealingweb.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106222005/http://www.justdetention.org/pdf/HopeforHealingweb.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-01-06|format=PDF|accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref> Thus, short-term lockups, such as holding facilities, and local [[jail]]s, regardless of size, are also subject to the provisions of PREA.<ref name=cipp/> Failure by local authorities and operators of such facilities to comply with the provisions of PREA results in a 5% reduction in federal funding to that agency for each year they fail to comply.<ref name="cipp">{{cite web|url=http://www.cipp.org/sexual/index2.html|title=Police & Law Enforcement Short-Term Holding Facilities (Lock-Ups) & the Prison Rape Elimination Act: Information and Assistance for Law Enforcement & Chiefs of Police|publisher=The Center for Innovative Public Policies|accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref>
==Implementation==
===Grants=== PREA authorizes money in the form of [[grant (money)|grant]]s for a wide variety of implementation associated activities. The grants can be utilized by state agencies for personnel, training, technical assistance, data collection, and equipment to prevent, investigate, and prosecute prison rape. Each state recipient is required to submit a report within 90 days laying out on what activities the money was spent on as well as the effect of those activities on prison rape within the state. In 2004 Congress appropriated [[US$]]25 million dollars for the grant program and in 2005 US$20 million.<ref name=07update>{{cite web|url=http://www.spr.org/pdf/SPR_PREA_update_3-29.pdf|format=PDF|title=Prison Rape Elimination Act Update|date=March 2007|publisher=[[Just Detention International]]|accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref> The BJA handed out $10 million of the 2004 appropriation in the fourth quarter of that year. The largest grant amount that year, $1 million, was handed out to the [[Department of Corrections]] in [[Iowa]], [[Michigan]], New York, [[Texas]] and [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]].<ref name=2006rept/>
===Federal facilities=== {{Empty section|date=June 2008}}
===Immigration detention centers=== PREA also applies to all federal [[Immigration detention#United States|immigration detention centers]].<ref name="sprfs">{{cite web|url=http://www.justdetention.org/en/factsheets/Prison_Rape_Elimination_Act.pdf|format=PDF|title=JDI Fact Sheet: The Prison Rape Elimination Act|date=March 2009|publisher=[[Just Detention International]]|accessdate=2008-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101101215506/http://justdetention.org/en/factsheets/Prison_Rape_Elimination_Act.pdf|archivedate=2010-11-01|df=}}</ref> In December 2006, NPREC held two days of hearings focusing on sexual violence and rape in immigration detention facilities. During the hearings they heard testimony from a female victim of sexual assault in an immigration facility as well as testimony from prison staff. The panel issued a statement reiterating that its policy of "zero-tolerance" applied to federal immigration facilities.<ref name="immpr">{{cite web|url=http://www.nprec.us/docs/nprec_ps121506.pdf |format=PDF |title=Bi-partisan commission emphasizes "zero tolerance approach" to sexual violence in U.S. immigration facilities |date=2006-12-15 |publisher=[[National Prison Rape Elimination Commission]] |accessdate=2008-06-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008160928/http://www.nprec.us/docs/nprec_ps121506.pdf |archivedate=October 8, 2007 }}</ref> In oral statements made by the U.S. delegation to the [[United Nations Convention against Torture#Committee against Torture|Committee Against Torture]] in 2006, Thomas Manheim with the U.S. DOJ responded to queries by Nora Sveaass about the implementation of PREA in immigration detention facilities. Some of the steps Manheim asserted [[Department of Homeland Security]] has taken included the development of a classification system to segregate violent and non-violent offenders, "widespread posting of instructions on how to report sexual misconduct", and PREA training for detention officers in the facilities.<ref name="oralstatement">{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/66174.pdf |format=PDF |title=Oral Statements by the United States Delegation to the Committee Against Torture |last=Manheim |first=Thomas |date=2006-05-06 |publisher=[[United States Department of State]] |pages=13 |accessdate=2008-06-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516022203/http://www.state.gov/documents/organization/66174.pdf |archivedate=2008-05-16 |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
===Juvenile facilities=== NPREC held hearings focusing specifically on the elimination of juvenile prison rape victims on June 1, 2006.<ref name="juvhearing">{{cite web|url=http://www.nprec.us/proceedings_boston.htm |title=Hearing: Elimination of Prison Rape: Focus on Juveniles - June 1, 2006 |date=2006-06-01 |publisher=[[National Prison Rape Elimination Commission]] |accessdate=2008-06-13 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080804085006/http://www.nprec.us/proceedings_boston.htm |archivedate=2008-08-04 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Individual states have sought to comply with the mandates of PREA concerning juveniles, for instance, the Massachusetts Department of Youth Services worked with consultants from the Moss Group, Inc. to develop PREA policies and training.<ref name=buckley>{{Cite news| last =Pihl-Buckley| first =Heidi| author-link =| author2-link =| title =Tailoring the Prison Rape Elimination Act to a Juvenile Setting| newspaper =Corrections Today| pages =| year =2007| url =http://www.aca.org/publications/pdf/Pihl-Buckley.pdf| format =PDF| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110718201921/http://www.aca.org/publications/pdf/Pihl-Buckley.pdf| archivedate =2011-07-18| df =}}</ref>
===Local, state and county facilities=== {{Empty section|date=June 2008}}
===U.S. Armed Forces=== {{Empty section|date=June 2008}}
==Research and studies==
===Annual reports=== In December 2007 [[United States Department of Justice]] published its 2006 report about rapes and sexual violence in American prisons. The report, which included information obtained from about 1.3 million prisoners, reported 60,500 cases of sexual violence ranging from unwanted touching to rape in 2006.<ref name=kaufman/> In total, 4.5 percent of American prisoners reported an incident of sexual violence in the study.<ref name=kaufman>Kaufman, Pat. "[http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/nij/journals/259/prison-rape.htm Prison Rape: Research Explores Prevalence, Prevention]", ''NIJ Journal'', No. 259, March 2008, ''[[National Institute of Justice]]'', [[United States Department of Justice]], accessed June 5, 2008.</ref>
===Congressional findings=== The U.S. Congress, within the text of PREA, conservatively estimated that at least 13 percent of the inmates in the United States have been [[sexual assault|sexually assaulted]] in [[prison]].<ref name=sigler/> Under this estimate, nearly 200,000 inmates now incarcerated have been or will be the victims of prison rape. The total number of inmates who have been sexually assaulted in the past 20 years likely exceeds 1,000,000."<ref name=sigler>Sigler, Mary, "By the Light of Virtue: Prison Rape and the Corruption of Character", ([http://ssrn.com/abstract=896784 Abstract w/ link to document]), ''Iowa Law Review'', Vol. 91, pp. 561-607, 2006, accessed June 5, 2008.</ref> These numbers were derived based on the "testimony of social scientists and penologists".<ref name=sigler/>
===Contracted research=== PREA mandated that the NIJ provide funding for research conducted by private contractors, considered experts within the field. In 2006 alone, NIJ funded three major studies of sexual assault in prison.<ref name=07update/>
One study, initially released in January 2006 before being finalized or peer reviewed,<ref name=07update/> by Mark Fleisher at [[Case Western Reserve University]] showed that prison rape was rarer than estimated.<ref name=msnbc/> Fleisher's study reported that most prisoners who claim to have been raped are looking for money, publicity, a transfer, or lying. The study was immediately questioned and disputed by members of NPREC. Both [[Reggie B. Walton]], NPREC chair, and commissioner Cindy Struckman-Johnson spoke out against the study, with Struckman-Johnson calling it unscientific.<ref name=msnbc>"[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/10896343/from/RS.2/ Disputed study: Prison rape, sexual assault rare]", ''[[Associated Press]]'' via [[MSNBC.com]], January 17, 2006, accessed June 5, 2008.</ref> Fleisher released a substantially revised version of the report in November 2006, Stop Prisoner Rape (now [[Just Detention International]]) stated it was "still plagued by many of the same fundamental flaws as the initial version."<ref name=07update/>
==Reaction== The speed with which the bill passed, and the fact it was passed without public pressure, has been called "surprising".<ref name=teret/> PREA went through both houses in July 2003, was presented to the president on September 2, 2003 and signed two days later. Human Rights Watch urged President Bush to sign the bill, and stated that if it were implemented correctly it would "catalyze nationwide efforts to eliminate prison rape by inmates and correctional staff."<ref name=hrwpr>{{cite press release| title = U.S.: Bush Should Sign Prison Rape Legislation| publisher = [[Human Rights Watch]]| date = July 31, 2003| url = http://hrw.org/english/docs/2003/07/31/usdom6277.htm| accessdate =2008-06-06 }}</ref>
[[Robert Weisberg]], co-writing with David Mills, argued in ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' in October 2003 that PREA did little more than collect data. They argued that the bill's original title, the "Prison Rape Reduction Act", was probably a more likely predictor of its outcome.<ref name="weisberg">{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2089095/|title=Violence Silence: Why No One Really Cares About Prison Rape|last=[[Robert Weisberg|Weisberg, Robert]] and Mills, David.|date=2003-10-01|publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref> A similar position was put forth by [[Mike Farrell]], writing in [[The Huffington Post]], where he stated, "the National Prison Rape Elimination Commission meets periodically to 'study the impact of prisoner rape.' While they study, rape continues."<ref name="farrell">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mike-farrell/ending-the-hidden-savage_b_91867.html|title=Ending the Hidden, Savage Routine of Prison Rape|last=[[Mike Farrell|Farrell, Mike]]|date=2008-03-17|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Prison rape in the United States]] *[[Sexual abuse of women in American prisons]] *[[Just Detention International]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *Beck, Allen J., et al. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20080510200151/http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs///pub/pdf/svrca06.pdf Sexual Violence Reported by Correctional Authorities, 2006]", ([[PDF]]), ''[[Bureau of Justice Statistics]]'', August 2007, accessed on June 5, 2008. *Fleisher, Mark and Krienert, Jesse. "[http://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/nij/grants/216515.pdf The Culture of Prison Sexual Violence]", ([[PDF]]), November 2006, ''[[National Institute of Justice]]'', accessed June 5, 2008. *Mariner, Joanne, et al. [https://www.hrw.org/reports/2001/prison/report.html No Escape: Male Rape in U.S. Prisons]", ''[[Human Rights Watch]]'', 2001, {{ISBN|1-56432-258-0}}, accessed June 5, 2008. *Ristroph, Alice, "Sexual Punishments", ([http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=883737 Abstract w/ link to document]), ''Columbia Journal of Gender and Law'', Vol. 15, No. 139, 2006, accessed June 5, 2008. *Smith, Brenda V. and Yarussi, Jamie M. "Prosecuting Sexual Violence in Correctional Settings: Examining Prosecutors' Perceptions", ([http://ssrn.com/abstract=1129816 Abstract w/ link to document]), ''Criminal Law Brief'' Spring 2008, [[American University]]: [[Washington College of Law]], WCL Research Paper No. 2008-50, accessed June 5, 2008. *Thomas, Dorothy Q., et al. "[https://www.hrw.org/reports/1996/Us1.htm All too Familiar: Sexual Abuse of Women in U.S. State Prisons]", ''[[Human Rights Watch]]'', 1996, {{ISBN|1-56432-153-3}}, accessed June 5, 2008.
==External links== {{wikisource}} {{Wikisource|Statement on Prison Rape Elimination Act}} *[http://nicic.org/PREA PREA - National Inst. of Corrections], ''[[National Institute of Corrections]]'', accessed June 5, 2008. *[http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/programs/prisonrapeelimination.htm Prison Rape Elimination Act Resources], ''[[Office of Justice Programs]]'', [[U.S. Department of Justice]], accessed June 5, 2008. *[http://nprec.us/ National Prison Rape Elimination Commission], official site, accessed June 5, 2008.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Prison Rape Elimination Act Of 2003}} [[Category:2003 in law]] [[Category:Prison rape in the United States]] [[Category:Penal system in the United States]] [[Category:United States federal criminal legislation]] [[Category:108th United States Congress]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 848528902 by [[Special:Contributions/The Anomebot2|The Anomebot2]] ([[User talk:The Anomebot2|talk]])

revision.text:
[[File:Man with a telescope in Prospect Park (92556).jpg|thumb|350px|Man in Brooklyn's [[Prospect Park (Brooklyn)|Prospect Park]] inviting passersby to use his telescope and talk about an [[astronomy|astronomical]] phenomenon.]]
'''Public science''' is an increasingly popular term for research that is conducted amongst, or includes, the [[public]]. Two traditions of public science have emerged, one based on [[participatory action research]] and another based on [[science outreach]].
The [[participatory action research]] approach seeks to develop a critical framework for making systematic inquiry and analysis a public enterprise. It is committed to valuing knowledges that have been historically marginalized and delegitimized (i.e., youth, prisoner, immigrant, farmer) alongside traditionally recognized knowledges (i.e., scholarly). Through the formation of research collectives, it aims to share the various knowledges and resources held by its individual members so members can participate as equally as possible. The choice of appropriate research questions, design, methods and analysis as well as useful research products are decided collectively. Centres for this form of public science include the [http://publicscienceproject.org/ Public Science Project] and the Society for Participation, Engagement, Action and Knowledge Sharing.
Examples of public science projects in the [[participatory action research]] tradition include the [http://morrisjustice.org/ Morris Justice Project] and [http://ourfood.org.uk/ Our Food].
The [[science outreach]] approach has some similarities to [[citizen science]] but typically describes projects that are conducted outdoors or in another type of public or accessible space such as a public park, metro stop, library, university campus, etc.<ref>Arcand, K.K., Watzke, M., “Creating Public Science with the From Earth to the Universe Project” Science Communication. September 2011. 33 (3) http://scx.sagepub.com/content/33/3/398.abstract. </ref> Similar to [[public art]], there are aspects of collaboration, community support and involvement, and even site specificity<ref>Watzke, M., Arcand, K.K., “The Universe Brought Down to the Streets: The “From Earth to the Universe” Project”. Mercury magazine. Volume 39 #1. Spring 2010. (excerpt: http://www.astrosociety.org/pubs/mercury/39_02/watzke.html)</ref> involved.
Public science efforts in the [[science outreach]] tradition include Science on the Buses, in which city buses in many major European Union cities were decorated with large informational science posters in November 2002. Likewise, a project in Toronto placed “advertisements” with science facts on [http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/01/06/busing-in-astronomy/] buses in Toronto during July 2009.
"Science City" is another example of a public science initiative that ran from June 1994 through May 1995. Created by staff and consultants from the New York Hall of Science, "Science City" was an outdoor exhibition that utilized the street, fences, buildings and other public structures in New York City to attract the "non-museum-going" public to the science in everyday life.<ref>Cole, P.R. & Cutting, J.M., 1996, “The Inside Story of Science City - An Outdoor Public Science Exhibition”. [[Curator: The Museum Journal]]. Volume 39 #4, p.245-261.</ref> The exhibition asked questions such as "Why is it warmer in the city?", "What pulses under the street?" and "What's under the sidewalk?" to help increase public awareness about the science and technology that runs invisibly underneath modern urban life.
[[Science Cafe]]s, founded by the public science pioneer [https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/apr/24/duncan-dallas/ Duncan Dallas] are a further public science effort that initiates a discussion on a science topic in pubs or cafes, usually with a local researcher in attendance to answer questions and present information.
[[Science festival]]s can also be grouped into this category of public science efforts, with modern incarnations of festivals including a range of learner-centered activities and events conducted in public spaces.
Public science initiatives often attempt to reach new audiences (particularly, non-experts who might not actively seek out science), in addition to existing science outreach audiences, by hosting events in alternative [[informal learning]] environments.<ref>Bell, P., Lewenstein, B., Shouse, A. W., Feder, M. A.(Eds). 2009, Learning science in informal environments: People, places and pursuits. Washington, D.C.: The National Academies Press.</ref> By definition, such public science projects are outside the walls of the [[Science museum#Science_center|science center]] or [[science museum]], where the main focus of the particular space is not typically science outreach.<ref>Norsted, B. A., 2010, “Take Me Out to the Ball Game: Science Outreach to Non-traditional Audiences” Science Education and Outreach: Forging a Path to the Future. ASP Conference Series, Vol. 431, p.170-173.</ref>
An example of a specific public science initiative in astronomy is “[http://www.fromearthtotheuniverse.org/ From Earth to the Universe]” (FETTU), a project of the [[International Year of Astronomy]] 2009 (IYA2009).<ref>Russo, P. and Christensen, L.L. (Eds.), 2010 “International Year of Astronomy 2009 Final Report” International Astronomical Union, {{ISBN|978-3-923524-65-5}}</ref> FETTU displayed large-scale images of astronomical objects with contextual information and supplementary materials and activities in non-traditional and mostly public locations such as parks, airports, art festivals, shopping malls, and others (see examples at http://www.fromearthtotheuniverse.org/event_photos.php). By 2011, FETTU had been exhibited at about 1000 sites worldwide, with 50 sites in the United States.<ref>Arcand, K.K., Watzke, M., 2010, “Bringing the Universe to the Street: A Preliminary Look at Informal Learning Implications for a Large-Scale Non-traditional Science Outreach Project”. JCOM Journal of Science Communication. Vol. 09, Issue 02, 1. http://jcom.sissa.it/archive/09/02/Jcom0902%282010%29A01/</ref> One result from FETTU demonstrated a trend towards more non-self-selective audiences for science communications in these public spaces.
== See also == * [[Participatory action research]] * [[Science outreach]] * [[Physics Outreach]] * [[Public art]] * [[Science museum#Science_center|Science Centers]] * [[Science museum|Science Museums]] * [[Science Cafe|Science Café]]s * [[Science festivals]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://publicscienceproject.org/ Public Science Project] * [http://www.astronomy2009.org/ International Year of Astronomy 2009] * [http://fromearthtotheuniverse.org/event_photos.php From Earth to the Universe] * [http://fettss.arc.nasa.gov/ From Earth to the Solar System] * [http://voyagesolarsystem.org/ Voyage to the Solar System] * [http://www.usasciencefestival.org/ USA Science and Engineering Festival] * [http://www.worldsciencefestival.com/ World Science Festival] * [http://www.sdsciencefestival.com/ San Diego Science Festival] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101126040458/http://www.sciencecafes.org/index.html Science Cafes.org]
{{Science and the public|state=autocollapse}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Public Science}} [[Category:Science in society]] [[Category:Public sphere|Science]]
